Being part of his Poem of the Fortunate ISLANDS, formerly written in French and Addreed to The KINGS MAJESTY.
Upon the Solemnity of His Aupicious CORONATION.

div.head: THE FORTUNATE ISLANDS.
Tranlated out of a Poem written in French, and formerly addreed to The MAJESTY of CHARLES II. Upon the Solemn Day of HIS CORONATION. PINDARICK ODE.
Stanza. I. Anwering the XXIV in the French.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: TOuch'd with that Flame which Poets Breats does warm,
The dark Events of things to come I pye,
Thrice Glorious KING! and dare not to deny
This truth which hould become a crime conceal'd
Poterity, did it lye unreveal'd,
Were therein much concern'd, whoe joy 'twill be
To know with what returns our Vowes for thee
Great Charles, came back from Heaven, but we much more
Concern'd to know, thou didt that joy retore,
To prove the Greatet King that ever a Scepter bore.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Know then, of Crowned heads the worthiet Head!
That ome kind Stars on us yet once hall mile,
And on this Ile
A golden Age in pight of Fate retrive;
Whilt thou our Pilot at the Stern hall it,
A Salomon for Prudence, Fame, and Wit,
Our Detinies to guide and happinee to mind;
This Globe again new Continents hall find,
Thy conqu'ring Navy a new Ophir yield;
And with new Titles fill thy Royal Shield.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Under that part of the divided Globe
Where lowe Bootes riding on Charles Wain,
(a) Is oft een in his lofty Orbe
To plough the furrowes of the Main:
And where the boldet Ships that nearer came
To make land, Therefore called Terra del fuego. never aw but flame
Standing at gaze amid't the Sea, there run
Spread under a new Pole by the Almighty Hand,
Long Tracts of vat and unknown Land,
A larger Continent this Earthly Globe hath none. This happens in the poition of the Sphere where the Line is Zenith.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: As much as gues by reaon led can find,
And of dark truths inform our mind,
Here tands in force yet Natures ancient Law,
Which harmles men by untaught rules do's aw;
Of uch this happy clime has tore,
Though a Gigantik race appear'd on hore
Where Viz. about 47. gr. South Latitude, where a ort of very tall men hath been feen. colder aire breeds ruder wits;
From 15. to 30. gr. S. lat. a goodly land runneth, of which the Hollanders are aid to have ome Maps, but kept by them concealed to this day. But neer the Sun heat does infue the eed
Of a more vertuous race, and kinder breed,
Among whom yet unwrong'd fair Virgin Nature its.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: There, next th' imbalmed groves where bright Aurora dwels,
In fragrant woods old Brachmans kept their cells
In the worlds birth, and on this happy tage
Did celebrate the golden age,
Teaching of Souls th' immortal fall and pring,
Which Pythagoras thence to credulous Greece did bring.
There, great Jarchas the next Magi taught
The worlds Magnalia with hid knowledge fraught.
For whom a Apollonius Thyanaeus. curious Greek, his Seven wie forook,
And Athens thence return'd with unknown wonders trook.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: There, <note n="" place="bottom">Philoophorum. that kind teem which from tars drops on Earth,
When he breeds Metals, wells up bulky hills,
And with rich oare whole Countries fills,
O'repread with branches which betray their birth:
There in clear treams and crytal brooks, gold torn
From ome adjacent Mine where it was born,
Runs unregarded with vile pebbles mixt,
As if his juyce was yet unfixt;
And Silver hutes by Archaean. ecret heat provokt
In May Crytal Rocks, as Alpian ridges yoakt.

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: This land in Diamonds and Rubies warms,
As common tones in our fields ue to grow,
Their lovely green there Emeralds do betow,
Their quarries like fair meadows how;
There, without Fihers art, or divers toil,
That rich hoare yields the Orient hining Pearl
Freely expos'd upon th' imbroidred oyl,
And on each twig in woods, a worm does curl
Thoe hining bowels with it's own life pun,
Wherewith Kings houes trim'd out-hine the Sun.

lg.head: VIII.
lg.l: The Saphir, Amethyt, and Onyx there adorne
The grots of dearts by wie Natures care,
And the treakt Agath with it's chances born,
To whom his art no Graver can compare:
The changing Opall growing on the hore,
With more fair colours charmes the eye,
Then when the wond'rous Bow, or gay morn paints the skie;
And mother of Pearl there breeds in uch a tore,
That were it not for woods that yield a lov'lier hade,
Each Native might thereof have unbought houesmade.

lg.head: IX.
lg.l: But thee tall woods who were already grown,
When Time was infant yet, the world a babe,
Afford uch pleaant hade,
That eae it elf eems there to fix it's lating Throne:
Thoe Palaces to whom our Art
Does all the helps of wit and hand impart,
Where Porphyrie vain luxe to Marble joyns,
In their high pomp cannot out do
Thee rural manions, whoe hade entertains
Freely their guets with meat and helter to.

lg.head: X.
lg.l: There Pines and Cedars reaching to the skie,
Do raie a roof amazing tanders by,
Whil't th' humble myrtle which embalm's the fields,
Perfum'd walls next to the foundation yields.
The fragrant Jels'min, and weet Orange-tree
Common, as Fern and Broom are with us een,
Frame a contexture of their lating green;
All Flora's tore either for mell or eye
Makes a Moaik floore mixt with ilky mos,
Whoe glitering down doves neck's in Sun hine does urpas.

lg.head: XI.
lg.l: There, the kind Earth untoucht with plough or pade,
And without drops from careful Tillers brow,
All orts of fruits for Sight or Palate made
On happy mortalls does betow.
There weet Potatoes growing in each ground,
And milky Coco's in each forret found
Afford unbought and free meals in each place,
Andwithout hands of cooks each common table grace,
Then to upply for drink the want of forrain wines
Her pleaant ap, to its better juice, the weet Palmite joyns.

lg.head: XII.
lg.l: Bacchus and Ceres here
Do always freely Crown the year,
Though field for it be never torn,
With fruits enough their Altars to adorn;
Not that the willing earth hould there her crops refue
If Husbandmen their skill did ue:
The Stars are there too gentle and too kind,
And did care vigor add to the elf growing vine,
Under the leaning grapes the cruhed props hould pine,
And for one ventur'd corn the Sower thouands find.

lg.head: XIII.
lg.l: But where free nature with uch bounty fills
Our treaures with its own rich tore,
What madnee to repine & crave for more;
Or controle with our Art what her own prudence wills?
O! fond attempt of humane pride!
Which would through other paths our wanton actions guide
Then thoe, which her own hand do's for us wiely trace;
And you, thrice happy mortals! whom that place
Does entertain without ambitious care,
To add to what her love appoints to be your hare!

lg.head: XIV.
lg.l: There your calm numerous years do gently lide
O happy mortals! without pain or grief;
Untill your tars become your guide
To ilent dut, and death, which with joys pat belief
You do embrace; you happy whilet alive!
Whoe well-tun'd minds were never put to trive
Againt your crazy bodies tott'ring frame,
But kept unpotted your Celetial flame
From Tyrant paions ever free,
And from all pots of frail mortalitie.

lg.head: XV.
lg.l: There next Aurora's Palace where the Morn
Keeps contant watch, oft Zephyrus awak't
And charm'd with love of his fair Nymph each day
Comes perfum'd with the Sun in Flora's groves,
And there his amber-ighs does ilently diplay,
Whip'ring to chirping birds how fair a Nymph he loves;
Thee Groves then whom the Sun no weeter ees,
A thouand dales with native flow'rs do paint,
Which pleaantly confound the gazers eyes,
And in their miling looks through heat nor cold nere faint.

lg.head: XVI.
lg.l: There neither torm nor harp Chiroco's blat
Does any dicord 'twixt the Seaons cat,
A contant Spring the gay birds entertains,
And for their nets a contant green maintains,
Whence porting they as long as are the days,
'Twixt harmlee love and pleaant layes,
With fear or pining care their happy lives nere tint;
The Sun by which their lungs are tun'd
Does thouand colours on their feathers print
The Eye to entertain, whilt that the Ears are charm'd.

lg.head: XVII.
lg.l: There the bountiful Sea by kind heat cheriht til
With rare and unknown cates her fruitful womb do's fil,
Through waves of Chrital bright and clear
Her well tor'd bottome does appear:
There in pure Brooks that wiftly run,
And in their race their own tream hun,
Many rare Fih his ilver cales diplayes.
Edging the tat by ight, there as a common dih
The bright Dorado cloth'd with golden rayes
Is daily erv'd, and there each ene enjoyes his wih.

lg.head: XVIII.
lg.l: That brakih tat which other Seas infets,
Vexing with naueous mells her queamih guets,
Is baniht thence, her perfum'd froth that breaks
Each day on Shore, leaves there great amber cakes;
There many branch of precious coral torn
From its concealed tree, does the rich trand adorn;
A trand where oft winds ever mile,
And weaves do only rie in port,
Where no rocks Seamen do beguile
Nor torms caue hipwrack in the port.

lg.head: XIX.
lg.l: That famous Bird which Nature made
Sole Mater of his life expir'd,
Which only we know in the hade
Of dark truth in times cell retir'd;
The Phoenix which his dayes alone
Knows to retrive when they are gone,
And of all mortal agents can
Lengthen at will his own lifes pan,
Above all others do's affect that Soyle
Where for his death each wood affords a Funeral pile.

lg.head: XX.
lg.l: That other bird whom we may call
Of other birds the truet guet oth' sky,
Which from his pitch does never fall,
And takes his Name from where departed Saints do fly;
The Paradice bird, who without help of wings,
Supended by ome truer prings
Does never touch our earths defiling pot,
Above all climes this chues for his lot;
Where never civil war does 'twixt the eaons rie,
Nor hoary frots do check the mildnes of the skies.

lg.head: XXI.
lg.l: There, our eyes ee in truth what all thoe wanton
Of dreaming Poets in their heated veyne,
Under fale praies wrote of their Elizian plaine tales
In time of old; There a treame never fayles
Of harmles mirth, of ports and youthful playes
To court our ene, and oftly teal our dayes
In contant joy, in pight of envious time;
And what in Fables Poets old
Of happiet countries have us told,
We find in real truth in this mot happy clime.

lg.head: XXII.
lg.l: This is that Famous Ile which a Plato. Great Sage
Long ince reveal'd the world a Seneca the Tragedian. Poet ung,
The Great Atlantis which our age
Hath waited for, and unknown prais'd o long;
Th' Heperian Grove to none but our Alcides free:
There Plenty, Peace, and Mirth are long ince fled
Frighted by dimal jarres, untill by Thee
They be retriv'd, GREAT PRINCE, and as thy vaals led
To hare the honour of this happy day,
And at thy Sacred Feet their frutes for ever lay.

lg.head: XXIII.
lg.l: Go then, and proper, Magnanimous King,
Gather thoe Bays which for Thee only pring,
Let all Advent'rers graceing Thy deeine,
To this jut Conquet their bet tars reigne;
And thou whoe blood with Cezars blood is mixt,
Whoe bold attempts have Fortunes favour fixt,
Oft to thy Sword, or through her frowns made way
To reach thy elf and thine the long'd for Bay,
Lend us, Brave RUPERT, both thy Head and Hand,
All Seas by CHARLES allow'd will toop at thy command.

lg.head: XXIV.
lg.l: Thou hat enough with thy bright Name
Filled the trump of Fame,
Her voice and lungs by praiing thee
Almot exhauted be:
Europ enough in thee our parts hath een
Of thy brave deeds the glory hine;
Go, fill the unknown world with thy renown,
And there proclaime the Britih Crown,
Thy Heart exceeds what with us may be done,
Call for new witnees under a new Sun.

lg.head: XXV.
lg.l: Under thy Conduct and victorious armes
Matcht to the Britih colours, Right hall aw
The yielding Ocean, and retore that Law
Which hips does free from greedy Pyrats harms;

l.hi: The Great Name of our CHARLES

lg.l: A trong afegard to helter us and and thee,
Shouldt thou meet with oppoing rage.
And Heav'n it elf with thee will joyn in hare,
To bles with Peace and Plenty this our Age,
In part of thoe returns we expect from thy care.

div.head: FORTUNATARUM INSULARUM DESCRIPTIO POETICA.

PRO INAUGUTATIONE CAROLI II. E GALLICO TRANSLATA: ET ILLUSTRISSIMO PRINCIPI RUPERTO PALATINO, &c. Rerum Maritimarum expertiimo, & Anglicarum Coloniarum promovendarum tudioiimo, in obequii perpetui Monumentum ab ipo Authore, P. D. C. Dicata.

lg.head: STANZA. I.
lg.l: PLenus Appollineo quae int ventura calore
Auguror, (et vatum mens praecia nempè futuri)
Nec mea Mua ilens audet quae fata recondunt
Sub tenebris preie, decet quae cire nepotes.
Illos cire velim notris quàm Numina votis

Non duras vertêre aures, quám
que illa ecundis
Nos ultro implerint ucceibus omine fauto:
Verùm & nos quoque cire iuvat, quàm laeta futuris
Temporibus per Te nacentur aecula Mundo
Et Triplicis quantùm tibi crecet gloria Sceptri.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Dice ergo, Regum Rex ô digniime! notris
Carminibus doctus, quantùm indulgentia coeli
Te nobis Regnante dabit, quòdque illa erenos
Quales & primis Saturnia aecla dedêre
Sponte uâ terris, reparabit provida oles,
Vel Parcâ renuente tuo, Rex Maxime, ductu:
Magnus Idumaeis ut quùm regnabat in oris
Schelomo, terrarum nova Nereus adyta pandet,
Alter erit tùm Typhis & altera fluctibus Argos
Quae Fortunatas reerat Te Vindice Terras.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Et Locus oppoito quo volvitur orbis in axe,
Hoc contingit in poitione Sphaerae rectae, & maxima parte Autralis Hemipherii. Fluctibus Oceani praeceps ubi mergitur Arctos,
Sedulâ ubi Naturae lutranti indagine limbum
Cingentem liquidae quicquid uperinnatat undae,
Praeter aquas Idcircò Continentis illius pars illa quae Hipanis Navigatoribus primùm innotuit, Terra del fuego dicta. igneque procul vidie micantes,
Nil hùc uque datum et, jacet haec incognita terra
Obvero vicina polo; Magnique Tonantis

Magnum opu •…
Totum enim Autralem Polum circumambit. ad lat. 13. gr. in aliquibus locis pertingens. ipa dies namque in e condere Phoebum
Et reparare videt, tadium pernicibus aequans
Exporrecta rotis, quo non et majus in orbe.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Si benè conjiciunt divino lumine tactae
Vatum animae, dictata vigent hîc prima recentis
Naturae, legesque colit (quas uadet honetum)
Incola foelicis Terrae, qui implice cultu,
Semper inoffenae carpit olamina vitae;
Ad Autralem lat. 57. circiter gr. gens ferox & giganteae tatuiae a primis Navigatorib. via. Purcha. linchot. &c. Sunt tamen extremâ Titanum è emine ripâ
Vii aliqui, quorum plùs denas corpora palmas
Exuperant oculique truces, & fronte minaces:
Sed vicina Polo Gens haec; quae proxima Phoebo
Mitior, admittit meliores pectore cultus.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Hîc juxtà Eôos redolentes Cynnamon Hortos,
Invia Brachmanes nemorum ylvasque ecuti,
Innocui Samiae coluerunt dogmata Sectae,
Aure áque emeritis celebrârunt aecula Mytis;
Hîc veterum fido quondam Schola vera Magorum
Excepit mandata inu dictantis Iarbae,
Ver áque nacentis Sophiae monumenta recluit;
Huc eptem pretis Sapientibus impiger arit
Scil. Apollonius, qui Indiam Gymnoophitas inviurus peragravit. Sed haec Poeticè non hitoricè accipienda. Ille Thyanoeus Patriâ migrare relictâ,
Unde redux doctas Miraculis, de quibus fuè Jamblichus in Vitâ Pythagorae <> it. factis tupefecit Athenas.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: Hîc Scil. ille decantatus Philoophorum, anima vera Univeri. Coeli influxus,, quo decendente, fera •••
Parturiens uccos, turgecit vena metalli
Montibus in celis, varios per viceraramos
Divitis effingit Terrae, Proprium apud metallarios authores vocabulum, quo ramuculi venae in varias partes ee ab arbore, ive trunco praecipuo, diffindentis ignificantur. virgaque repentes;

Aurum granulatum, quale à primis Hipaniolae detectoribus ub Columbo, in meridionali parte Inulae circà Cibao, affatim in rivulis reperiebatur. ab Hipanis Scriptorib. operari • que Oro di pepone dictum, illudque optimum. Multa illîc liquido e proluit aurea rivo.
Lamina nativi fugiens de germine trunci,
Inficit & tremulas flaventi lumine lymphas,
Qualémque auricomus volvit Pactolus arenam:
Hic quoque candentes argentea fodina venas,

Talis fuie refertur a Scriptoribus Indicis nobilis illa Per •
viana argentifodina in Potoi, quùm primùm detecta in al <> ublimatos puri metalli ramos protrudens; argumentum cert •… validum adverùs vegetationem & vitam metallorum negantes, & principiis Peripateticis mordicùs nimiùm inhaerentes. Trudit in excelum, vegetóque cacumine urgit.

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: Igneus hîc Adamas faelicis cortice glebae
Delitet, hîc rutilos carbunculus exerit ignes,
Hîc viridis mutat campos in prata Smaragdus
Vilis ut in notris micet e calculus agris:
Hîc fallaci hamo, hîc urinatore remoto,
Gemmea Choncharum proles ad littoris oras
Sponte venit notros nondùm docta unio luxus;
Et quas arte parant plendenti è vellere Seres
Regum delicias, animâ & pirante minitrat
Bombyx fila, uis pendent paim obvia Sylvis.

lg.head: VIII.
lg.l: Sapphyrus hîc & parvus Onyx, Amethytus & ardens
Inter axa micant, pulis & gemma tenebris
Incultis Phoebi radios imitatur in antris;
Hîc in marmoreo ludens Natura Gagate,

Artificis uperat coelum, varii
que coloris
Opalus agnatos coeli ignibus excitat ignes,
Et rutilis teriles flammis accendit arenas:
Gemmea choncha natat pretioi in littoris Orâ
Multa, adeóque frequens, grato ut nî vertice Sylvae
Obtegerent, quique hinc ibi conderet incola caas.

lg.head: IX.
lg.l: Verùm hae quas infans vidit Naturaub Orbe
Nacenti, rerum & primaevâ ab origine ylvae
Crecentes, nullâque unquam violata ecuri
Robora, tranquillas praebent cultoribus umbras,
Sub viridi emper uadentique otia ramo:
Nec tantùm hopitibus placeant quae tecta uperbo
Ad coelum tollunt vicina cacumina fatu,
Magnatum inanae moles, & mentis & artis
Difficiles partus, ubi fulcit japida marmor,
Quantùm haec, Ambroiis emper reclua ub auris.

lg.head: X.
lg.l: Cedrus odorato coelum propè vertice tangens
Summa tenet, myrtúque humili pavimenta coronâ
Cingit, & exhalat precioi floris odores.
Jeleminum auratis & grata aurantia pomis,
Hîc uavi Zephyros paim piramine mulcent;
Nec filice aut flavis plus gaudent notra genitis
Arva; hîc mille olo radiant circumundique flores.
Muaeu¯mque exurgit opus quo terra uperbit,
Vericolore levis contecta & gramine muci,
Molliùs occurrit pedibus quàm vellera Serum.

lg.head: XI.
lg.l: Fertilis hîc genium terrae non vomer aratri
Sollicitat, nàm ponte uas dat legibus almae
Provida Naturae praecripto tempore mees;
Hîc paim dulci aturatus tubere campus
Patatae, Cocoque nucis dulcedine ylvae
Exornant laetis innoxia fercula menis:
Hîc Palmitae arbos nativo turgida ucco
Corticeóque penu latices effundit amaenos,
Nectareóque refert pomis onerata racemos
E longè advecti compenans munera Bachi.

lg.head: XII.
lg.l: Liber & alma Ceres hîc dextrâ emper amicâ
Muneribus terram faecundis ponte coronant,
Ancipitique pei amoto udore coloni,
Exornant proprias votivis frugibus aras;
Attamen hae cultore carent, quòd i addita cultrix

Ars Genio foret ulla loci terrae
que Vigori,
Hîc adeò blandos demittunt ydera fluxus,
Obrutus ut proprii palmes ub mole racemi
Vix jàm maturae toleraret pondera prolis,
Millenóque Ceres ditaret foenore ulcos.

lg.head: XIII.
lg.l: Sed quùm tàm largâ depromat munera dextrâ
Sponte uâ Natura parens, & divite cornu
Nos beet, inano quid nos potiora furore
Quaerimus, & fuco leges violamus avitas
Artifici; prudens quas olim implice cultu
Servandas, tenero Matris praecripit amore?
O hominum vanae mentes! obductáque caecis
O nimiùm emper mortalia corda tenebris!
Túque ô faelicis faelicior incola terrae;
Cui atis et natale olum, ambitione remotâ!

lg.head: XIV.
lg.l: Illîc annorum eries longaeva tuorum
Labitur, & tacito ua per vetigia curu
Fatorum ad metam faelicia tamina ducit
Morborum involata lue, vel debilis aevi
Ingratis vitiis, illîc reparata vigoris
Corpora flore novo, nunquàm languore faticunt:
Inque uo tranquilla manet mens laeta receu,
Officiique memor, caeleti ab origine lapae
Virgineo in cultu conervat emina flammae,

Pandorae
que dolos & tritia munera temnit.

lg.head: XV.
lg.l: Hîc juxtà Eô • s pirantes cinnama tractus,
Antevenit primos perfuus odoribus ignes
Aurorae Zephyrus, blanda & upiria fundens,
Aera per liquidum Florae patiatur in hortis;
Florae hortis quorum per amaenas lillia valles
Micentur violis, & uadent ducere ommos
Tótque adeò induxit campis Natura colores,
Ditracta ut dubitent ee quò lumina vertant,
Dùm ulcos nec ladit hyems, nec Syrius urit.

lg.head: XVI.
lg.l: Nunquàm hîc temperies annive evertitur ordo
Grandine, vel nimbis, Boreâve immane furenti;
At inter virides, omnîque in tempore, ramos
Garrula ponit avis nidum, prolique futurae
Pignora cara uae ecurâ ervat in umbrâ:
Indè uos cantus longis cum olibus aequat,
Cantibus & teneros querulis immicet amores,
Sic fugiente aevo, nullâque exterrita fraude:
Quique animam inpirat ol, idem mille colores
Effingens pennis, antè aurem lumina pacit.

lg.head: XVII.
lg.l: Hîc emper faecunda Thetys numeroa natantum
Agmina deducit, findentum caerula pinnâ
Marmora pernici, liquidis dùm ingit in undis
Squama nitens varios reflexâ luce colores,
Grata quibus fulvi concedat lamna metalli;
Illîc in liquidi laticis inuante recuru,
Multus inaurato picis ub cortice tutus
Delitet, & facilem primò per lumina gutum
Sollicitat enúque adeò plus implice gaudet
Objecto, atque homines Divûm ceu nectare pacit.

lg.head: XVIII.
lg.l: Illîc quae duros alio ub ydere nautas
Offendens nares autero vellit odore,
Doris amara uam non micet fluctibus undam;
Spumae intar grato uffitu littora ditat;
Plurima nativo'rubet hîc avula cubili
Arbor coralii Tyrio rutilantior otro,
Et ramo liquidos exornat divite ulcos;
Queis contenta Thetys poliis, ibi plura recuat
Quaerere naufragio, Boreae aut ditecere damnis.

lg.head: XIX.
lg.l: Hîc Ales proprios cui jus conceit in annos
Indulgens Natura, ui quique arbiter aevi
Illudit fatis, nec decantata Sororum
Curat penatrium, quem non nii carmine nobis
Aut tabulis uovie datum: Vitae ille magiter,
Qui quùm vult rapidos vel itit temporis orbes,
Vel revocat, proprióque recens è funere urgit,
Phoebi ales Phoenix, hîc tutam figere edem
Quaeiit antè alias quùm it placidiima terras,
Omnis ubi dat ylva rogum dùm fata rearcit.

lg.head: XX.
lg.l: Hîc quóque non ficto coeli quae nomine dici
Incola, quaeque uis edes aptare beatas
Gaudet Apis titulis, Paradii nobilis ales,
Corpore librato quae emper pendula nubes
Pervolat, & notrae fugiens contagia terrae,
Acris ad libitum liquidi per inania fertur,
Radicéque ipo rurùs in aethere figit,
Has aliis prudens terrarum praetulit oras,
Coeli ubi concordes Naturae foedera ervant,
Nec brumae Zephyros violant, nec nubila oles.

lg.head: XXI.
lg.l: Hîc velo amoto, ibi quae ceu omnia finxit
Vulgi error, vanóque vetus quae carmine Vates,
Elyio adcripit mendax & Fabula campo,
Cernere vel tetigie licet, nec ficta voluptas
Deliciis animum vanâ ub imagine ludit,
Sempérque hîc objecta movent gratiima enfus,
Credere vix alio pois quae vera loquenti;
Quicquid & Hesperidum celebratis credula pomis
Alcinoique hortis tribuit, rurique Beato
Graecia, faelici hîc potior dat gleba colono.

lg.head: XXII.
lg.l: Denique, decantata haec et illa Inula Magno
Quae quondam detecta Platoni de Atlantide in Timaeo tractanti. Sopho, & celebrata Senec. Tragaedo in Medeâ. Poëtae,
Atlantis non Elyiis ceura beatis,
Quaeque nii Alcidae notro fit pervia nulli.
Hùc procul à notris fugit Pax Alma querelis
Et pacata quies notro vexata tumultu
Otia tranquilli quaerens ecura receus,
Undè Tibi comites cupient, Rex Magne, reverti
Et ociam praebendo manum Tua Sceptra tueri
Semper, & aeternas Te juxtà ponere edes.

lg.head: XXIII.
lg.l: Ergò age, Magnanime ô! Princeps, Tua fortibus urge
Fata animis, tantas propera decerpere palmas,
Sacraque legitimâ circumdare tempora lauro,
Annuat ut jutis mirans Europa triumphis:
Miles eat, nutúmque tuum aupiciúmque equatur;
Túque ô! Caeareos Auguti temmatis Avos
Qui equeris meritis, & cujus plendida virtus
Fortunam uperavit ovans, Martique pericla
Sprevit inoffeno ua per vetigia curu,
Conilio dextrâque juva haec incepta Roberte!

lg.head: XXIV.
lg.l: Jam at Fama tuos, Princeps generoe, labores
Multiloquâ parit Mundi per compita linguâ,
Ac tua narrando propè jàm pulmone faticit,
Jàm tantum detrectat onus, nec facta referre,
Nec dictis aequare potens, pernicior alis
Fortior aut i voce foret; at nota, per Aulas
Europae tua facta volant, empérque potenti
Decantata tubâ Famae ine fine vigebunt:
Jàm tetes tibi quaere novos, aliâque ub Arcto
Et ub Sole novo, tua plendeat inclyta virtus.

lg.head: XXV.
lg.l: Dùm tua Vexillis fuerint ociata Britannis
Arma, quibus ee emper Fortuna faventem
Praebet, & aeternas nectit Victoria palmas,
Oceano rediet tandem reverentia legum
Prica renacentum; Carolino Nomine tutus
Ceu clypeo incedes, tempetatúmque periclis
Eripiêre, furens i quando minabitur Auter:
Atra tuis etiam ridebunt propera ceptis,
Et tecum Pax alma redux & Copia edes
Hîc figent ibi perpetuas, illo orbe relicto.

div.head: OCCRSS REGIS In TAMESI.

Julio obeunte A. 1661. Carmine extemporaneo concriptus hortatu Magnatis Anglici meritiimi. Et Illutriimo GILLELMO C. DEVONIAE, Poëeos omnique politioris literaturae digniimo Mecaenati optimóque judici, In obervantiae & gratitudinis tetimonium DICATUS. A Nunquám dignè atis amica in e collata officia & beneficia peroluturo. P. D. C.
div.l: VEpere ub tacito, liquidis in Tameis undis,
Phoebus ad occiduas dùm properaret aquas;
Commodiora viae feus compendia longae
Quaerebam, & Anglis proprio vocabulo a Skullor dictâ. cymbâ paupere vectus eram:
Quùm ubitò Fluvium motos componere fluctus,
Et virides roeâ tingere luce comas
Adverti, Nympháque loci circumundique fuas
Intrepido vultu carpere umma lacus:
Rierunt croceo plendentes lumine ripae,
Mille upervolitant cripatum flumen Amores,
Auláque Nereïdum gemmea tota fuit.
Attonitus reputo quâ vi, quo Numine, tales
Extemplò ubeant aër & unda vices;
Quùm vox crebrecens ripae ad convexa, onoram
Officioa Echôn ollicitando ferit.
CAROLE viue diù, notrae, REX, gloria ripae,
Vive diù Britici gloria magna oli!
Per Te, moeta olim, taciturna ilentia rumpens
Jàm rediviva loquor CAROLE vive diù.

Undarum ingeminant Nymphae, plauú
que ecundos
Ipa dedit Doris Nereidúmque cohors;
CAROLE vive diù, notri ipes ola Tridentis!
Et Roeae aeternus it tibi frondis honos!
Nympha Tagi notris aderit mox laeta choraeis,
Et Tua gaudebit nectere erta ibi.
Protinùs obvertor: dùm CAROLUS, ecce, ecundo
Findebat placidas flumine vectus aquas,
Nabat & in cymba dans ua jura Salo.
Ponè equebantur deauratâ puppe Minitri,
Rex autem ligno implice vectus erat.
Tunc, pro more uo, ubridens fronte erenâ,
In nos, ut tranit, lumina acra jacit.
Cymba velox aetum autevenit Magno Hopite laeta,
Remorúmque citô verbere pula fugit.
Non pernix Aquilae citiori penna volatu,
Dùm praedam equitur, nubila cela ecat:
Non per caeruleos curu tàm praepete ulcos
Pinnarum remos Navita Prytis agit;
Non rapidos Delphin vincens conatibus Autros,
Non ubitam accelarans via colubra fugam;
Signat longa viam glicentis linea cymbae,
CAROLUS & radians fulminis intar abit:
Vixque avido Illîus potuit Vetigia niu,
Nereïdúmque cohors Doris & ipa equi.
En Deus ille, inquàm, praeens en Numinis aura,
Cujus am ant nutus aer & unda acros.
Verùm acies adeò celeri par luminis ee
Notra fugae nequiit, ceit & ipa dolens.
Vocibus auditis ergò mea carmina micens
Voce equor repetens, CAROLE vive diù:
Vivant jura Roae, rutilos dùm Cynthius ignes
Condet, & in alis exorietur aquis.
Te modò ic videam (i plus mihi fata negârint)
Saepiùs ô! cymbâ paupere vectus eam.

div.head: Quicunque notra Latinè dignabitur legere,.
div.p: HIS paucis etiàm quae praefamur, pro olita Muarum comitate, Muas colentium humanitate, ne tantiper immorari dedignetur. Admonitum quippè illum cupimus, nos diù à Poetices (Latinae praecipuè, inter varios obervationum apices poitae) tudiis, per ortis iniquitatem avocatos (contrà votum carmina cribentium, quae eceum & otia quaerunt) olo animi ardorè, olâ aemulatione inter Vota publica OPTIMO PRINCIPI, cum caeteris fidorum ubditorum, bono die bona verba dicendi, ad deueta Parnai munia revocatos, hoc quantulumcumque operis, oratione verâ, ut olennitatibus accommodatiori, è vernaculo notro Gallico exarae: I • circò Lectoris amici & faventis indulgentiam ambire, non doctorum everitatem criticam (ub quâ proculdubiò nobis laborandum foret) invitare. Illam obtetamur, amplectimur; hanc deprecamur. Non inficias euntes, praeter phalmata multa quae huic opuculo ex incuriâ Typographi irreperunt, aliqua etiàm notra Proodiae leges violantia inventura iri. Sed quae peramus inventioni Poematis & Carminis venutati nihil ui precii detractura: quaedam i citiùs innotuient, nec adeò tumultuariè, ac totum penè ipum opus prodire cogitur, effua fuient, in meliùs (fateor) commutari poterant; quaedam verò ad propoitum adeò appoitè cadere via unt, ut verborum Emphaim & concinnitatem in Proodiae gratiam inflectere, carminique meliùs ic fluentis harmoniam peundare, quidquam immutando, nos poenituiet. Condonet ergò, Lector <1… pages missing>

div.head: In the Fortunate Ilands. Englih.
